bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 8, 1900

div1.p: Reed reassures Emilie Lawrence Reed about yellow fever, claiming there is no danger. He writes about work done at Keewaydin and explains how he is organizing his laboratory.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 8, 1900
div1.opener:
No. 15 8.30 P.M.
See that
our pre-
cious joy
has a good time
on her birthday
Mother dear- Kiss
her many times for
her darling Papa.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados,
Cuba,
July 8, 1900
Love to auntie & the girls.
My own precious wifie:
div1.p:
You perceive
that I am writing this letter a
little later in the day than I am
accustomed- I wrote to that
small baby girl of ours early
this morning, and had proposed
to write to sweet farmer-lady
tomorrow morning; but as I
got another letter to-day (Sun-
day) as well as one yester-
day, I must write a little bit
to-night and finish in the morning.
I felt very certain, lovie, dear,
that when you saw that para-
graph about yellow fever
at Quemados, in the evening
Star, (I had seen it in Dr Stark's
paper) you would cut it out
and send it to me, and ask what
in the world it meant! I have
said nothing about yellow
fever, because I didn't want
to give you any worry, especially
as I wasn't myself taking
any risks whatever- There
have been two or three cases in
Quemados since our ar-
rival - one a member of the
hospital Corps, and another
a female nurse, both of whom
were nursing Mrs. Edmunds
who was down with the dis-
ease in an infected house
in Quemados. These cases are
now convalescing- Dr Kean is
over his attack and should
be in New Jersey by this
time, as he left Havana several
days ago- Dr Carrol & I have
been studying some cultures
which were made from the blood
of yellow fever, but there isn't a par-
ticle of danger in this- Please don't
pay any attention to anything you
see in the papers, for they always
get everything wrong- I couldn't
be in a safer place on the Island
than at Camp Columbia- By Genl
Lee's order, all Americans had al-
ready moved out of Quemados
before we got here- no soldier
is allowed to enter the town-
and no case has occurred for
about two weeks- The last,
I am told, was that of a Spanish
boy who lived about 2 miles
from here- When I get the dis-
ease, I promise that a Cable-
gram shall be promptly sent
to you- In the meanwhile, please
don't worry one particle- We
are not going into infected
houses nor to see patients with
the disease- we will confine our
work to material that Dr Agramon
te brings us- At present, there
are about a dozen cases in Havana,
but none of them at our disposal-
So please rest easy as far as
I am concerned- So you think,
sweetheart, that I get up too
early? well, I go to bed so early
and the mornings are so beau-
tiful that I can't resist the
temptation of an early bath-
You musn't forget that we have
breakfast at 7 a.m.! I enjoy
the early rising here very much,
and expect to get into such a con-
firmed habit, that I will be up
& chopping around in that aspara-
gus bed before 5 o'clock, when
I get back!- Boo! Boo! to you miss-
Good-night, you sweet joy!

WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.

Monday Morning-July 9th, Hello! lovie,
dear, how are you this bright,
beautiful morning? Why don't
you get out of bed & see the
sun rise? It would be far
better than snoozing away till
7.30 o'clock! By the way, sweet
farmer-lady, don't refer too
often to the good things you
have for breakfast, such
as fried chicken, waffles,
etc- We don't get those things
here in any large quan-
tity- I might say that we
don't get them at all! The
festive chicken doesn't ap-
pear to flourish to any con-
siderable extent on this Island.
Fish are more plentiful-
we get the Red Snapper, our
old mobile friend, in perfection.
I think that Johnnie Moore built
that piece of fence quite reas-
onably- By all means, have him
continue the fence down the
lane to meet Mr Flohr's piece
and then build your piece along
the edge of grotto Park- Per-
haps we will have stone enough
left to build, one of these days
on the other side of the road-
Don't cut down any more
trees, fat farmer-L, until
I get back- I want to bend
my large brain to that job!
Your darling letter of July 2nd
tells me that the wind has
stopped blowing and that it
is much cooler- 52° is certainly
remarkable weather for July,
even on the mountain- You
will now have a chance to
recover from that “washed
out” feeling! I can thoroughly
sympathize with you, for there
is nothing more annoying than
a continuous wind- I do
wish that you could have some
of our delightful rains here-
nearly every afternoon now
we have a good shower-
I think your strawberries
did very well for the first
year- They will bear 3 times
as many the second year, As
a morning dish they came
in very well after all- You
say that there are 25 raspberries
along the garden beds? I think
that I put out 3 dozen,
although I may be mistaken.
Its surprising that there should
be so few red raspberries
amongst the lot, as I can-
got some of them- I intended
to divide them amongst black &
red, with a few yellow thrown
in for good luck- How nice
to have the raspberries fol-
low the strawberries, and later
still to enjoy the black berries!
I am so glad that my darling
children can enjoy them for
breakfast- Don't forget that the
raspberry is decidedly consti-
pating for some people- See
that little big sweet Seventeen
doesn't get in that way with-
out saying anything about it-
A little liquorice powder ought
to remedy matters- I cannot
believe that three weeks have
passed since I left my pretty chil-
dren! How the time has flown!
By this time in August, I shall expect
to be on my way back home.
Am trying to get my laboratories in
as good shape as possible- Well, here
comes the mailman- Boo! Boo! sweet joys,
Love & Kisses for my pretty pinks-
